title: Will North Korea launch a land-based intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) before 1 November 2017?
preds: Yesterday’s successful intercontinental ballistic missile test marks a breakthrough in the country’s nuclear programme. The rocket that landed off Japan’s west coast yesterday followed a high, “lofted” trajectory whose range implies the missiles could travel 7,000km—enough to reach Alaska. That is striking progress, although the country is still far from having a reliable nuclear warhead. In January President Donald Trump promised that a North Korean ICBM test “won’t happen”; he may now look weak. That he recently claimed to have given up on getting help from China to curb the North’s nuclear ambitions won’t help either. Calls for new UN sanctions come as existing ones are poorly enforced. Some hawks argue for pre-emptive American strikes, but that would bring unthinkable retaliation risks for South Korea. Mr Trump promised a new direction on North Korea. Instead he is stuck with the old, lousy options
The United States -- which confirmed it was an ICBM launch -- backed by Japan and South Korea, requested the urgent meeting that is scheduled for 3 pm (1900 GMT).
U.S. Confirms North Korea Fired Intercontinental Ballistic Missile

The key to North Korea's "Crazy Man" strategy rests on the risk that there is a small - but credible - chance that it will do what it says and launch an attack. The US has effectively messaged to Kim Jung Un that it can discount their threats because we can now defend against an ICBM attack.  This does not necessarily reduce the risk of an North Korean attack - just the chance of an ICBM launch.  North Korea could still launch conventional attacks against South Korea or short-range ballistic missiles against Japan (which could presumably be defended by THAAD).

COMMENT:  This launch won't satisfy this question, but it tells me that Kim has not been deterred from doing as he plans/pleases, so until there's been additional sanctions imposed, I'll be expecting more launches.

I suspect that threats, pressure and some amount of cyber-related sabotage may make this an untenable proposition for NK this year. That said, this analysis is definitely sensitive to new developments and actions and reactions of actors outside NK. Not least the US and China.
On the BBC tv news tonight there was a story about China making it clear to DPRK that there will be consequences for this.

I think a test is extremely likely because the technology is developing rapidly (http://38north.org/2017/04/ychang042517/) and because I think Kim is a rational actor. He learned the lessons of NATO's Libya intervention and the US's second Iraq War (two examples of dictators abandoning their pursuit of nuclear weapons and thus leaving themselves open to attack) and understands that without a threatening arsenal of nuclear weapons he is not safe on his throne (is there a throne? I feel like there should be). My bet is our new president has him worried and he needs a way to demonstrate deterrence against a US attack, assuming of course the North Koreans haven't already worked out how to launch nuclear tipped missiles from submarines.
38 North recently posted an analysis of DPRKs missile capability.  http://38north.org/2017/04/ychang042517/

I'm betting that US will successfully pressurise China to stop economic relations with NK. And that will provide Kim three choices - (i) Let his country into ruin risking someone taking him out or an uprising; (ii) Make peace with the US / other global powers by shutting down his weapons development program; (iii) risk everything by going all out with a ICBM or worse.

Although there is a lot of data pointing to NK's ability to develop the weapon, the US's renewed vigor in monitoring the situation should deter the launch. China will also exert significant economic pressure on NK to not move forward. While Kim-Jong Un is certainly not the most rational actor, this combination of pressures should deter him at least until November 1st.

In 2016, NK has tested a nuclear device that can be assessed or verified.  Varying tests of components of the nuclear missile program has occurred as well since restarting nuclear production last year.  Whether  NK is capable of implementing a successful nuclear test is not is not quite clear -- given the size of the tremors near its nuclear plant where underground tests occurred, one can assume some level of success.   The various stages of component design, development, testing and launching (needs highly compotent scientists, fissile material and other factors) can occur within one or several cycles depending on the stage of technological development.  Since only one nuclear test has occurred (2016) but 5 over 2 decades that we know of, it is likely that there could be component ( or module) tests this year.  There is clear urgency and intentionality in weapons development, fissile production and testing given the current relations between NK and USA.  Given Pyongyang's bellicose rhetoric toward its rivals, it is capable of producing 6 kilograms of plutonium (a sufficient requirement for building 1 nuclear bomb) per year.  With prior production storage of fissile material, at this point, we know that has a capability of the use of 14 - 48 nuclear missiles.  While NK claims it can mount nuclear warheads on its missile and has the capability to employ an ICBM, it is less clear that this is the case.

Interesting analysis:
CSIS (Analysis), April 18, 'DPRK Provocations Possible Around South Korean Elections': http://beyondparallel.csis.org/rok-elections-and-dprk-provocations/
Clips from article:
"This new study is one of the first to examine the relationship between ROK elections and North Korean provocations with the key findings listed below.
Key Findings
The provocation window between South Korean elections and North Korean provocations has become more narrow over time. A previous Beyond Parallel study also found that North Korean kinetic provocations, including missile and nuclear tests, have clustered increasingly closer to U.S. elections.
Under Kim Jong-un, the average window for a North Korean provocation bracketed around all ROK elections is 6.5 days (about 1 week). The average for presidential elections is 15 days or about two weeks.
This represents a significant change from previous periods: Under the leadership of both Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il the window was an average of about 10 and 11 weeks respectively.
There has been a transformation in the types of kinetic provocations that North Korea has carried out over the last 20 years. The provocations are now overwhelmingly comprised of missile and nuclear tests rather than other types of conventional kinetic military actions.
This pattern suggests a provocation as early as two weeks before the South Korean elections on May 9th. The start of the provocation window falls on Military Foundation Day (April 25), a holiday in North Korea, and 10 days after the 105th anniversary of Kim Il-sung’s birthday on April 15th (KST).
